title: Winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak
body:
Winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak, winning streak, losing streak....


So fun to play this game. Wonderful matchmaking. Wonderful 50% win ratio forced to everyone regadless of if they are performing good or bad or the number of games played. (irony off).

In a winning streak you win even if you dont deserve it.
In a losing streak you lose even if you dont deserve it.

This game can go hell, tbh.

Not to agree or disagree with the point, but your "7 wins in a row" aren't random independent events.
First - you win a game you feel happy. You probably play better when you're happy. Also, you win a game you played well - your mind was clear things were going good. You play well one game you're likely to play well the next game. You're directly making your games correlated which makes these streaks much more likely. 

Then on top of that, matchmaking sort of encourages these streaks even if not intentionally. You win a bunch in a row (the last few maybe you get carried) and your MMR goes above what you deserve. Now you're not as good as your opponents and you lose a few in a row, then a few more because you're tilted from the losses (especially tilting when the losses are your fault because you weren't as good) and then your MMR goes below where you belong. Then you win some games because you're better and now you're playing well and happy from winning and win some more. It can go back and forth, where you build momentum to create a streak and eventually you break your boundary and get pulled back.

Now, I don't really believe Riot intentionally tries to force win or lose streaks on each person. I believe there are valid explanations for why they happen in a matchmaking system that's attempting to produce 50% win chance games (i.e. a fair system).

If you go on a winning streak, you will have higher MMR gains from each match and then will be put against players who also have higher MMR.

The whole purpose of MMR is to find the sweet spot where you are at 50% win rate.  If you have 50% winrate then you have arrived at your own personal MMR - where you are supposed to be in the ladder.

It is separate from LP gains.  It is possible to be at 50% winrate and still climb the ladder if your MMR is higher than where you currently are in the leagues.

(Or just boosting their teammates until they cant avoid to be carried, if it's the opposite way).

In a mmr matchup, if you start at 1500 and you are 2200, then you will win next to all your games, and your winrate will go from ~100% to ~50% bit by bit until you reach your 2200 elo. You wont find any losing streak either (variance happens, but those streaks will be short AND spaced, if any).

If it's the opposite, you start at 1500 but you belong to 800, then the opposite will happen. You wont find winning streaks either.

What happens in LoL is something different, they try to force a 50% W/L ratio until eventually you get your elo, instead of forcing equal elo in your matchmaking until eventually you reach 50% W/L. It works too, you will climb if you deserve that elo, it will not stuck you nor anything, BUT it will take you WAY WAY WAY more games to reach your actual elo, whatever it is.

I'll explain this very slowly so that you can make sense of it... 

Players with 1700 MMR are better then players with 1400 MMR.

Players who belongs at 1700 MMR have an easy time winning at 1400 MMR. This is because they are better players.

With me so far? 

Players who belong at 1700 MMR have an easy time winning at 1500 MMR, but not as easy as at 1400 MMR. This is because they are still better players, but by a smaller margin. 

Players who belong at 1700 MMR have a harder time winning at 1800 MMR. This is is because they are not as good as the other players. 

Players who belong at 1700 MMR have an even harder one winning at 1900 MMR. This is because they are much worse than the other players. 

I hope I haven't lost you yet. 

So, now that we understand that games get easier when your MMR is too low, and harder when it's too high, let's consider what happens with streaks. 

If you go on a losing streak, your MMR drops. What happens when your MMR drops? 

You guessed it, GAMES GET EASIER. 

So more the games are very easy, so you start winning a lot of games. What happens then? 

Yes, your MMR rises. And what happens when your MMR rises? GAMES GET HARDER! 

When games get harder, you start to lose more... 

And the cycle continues...

That is why you go on streaks.

Some players are conservative. They take few risks, and as such they tend to have few deaths, but they also rarely become the determining factor in their games. 

Other players are more aggressive. They take lots of risks. Sometimes those risks pan out and sometimes they don't. These players experience wide variations in their scores. When they're hot, they carry the game, and when they're not, they are a drag. 

Neither style is better than the other, but it's easy for a conservative player to blame an aggressive player when they're cold but not recognize that they're getting carried when they're hot because the conservative players tends to look pretty good when they're riding their coat tails.

Keep in mind that the players in your games win about as frequently as you do with and against the same people you're playing with and against, and more importantly, that players better than you beat those players and rise season after season without getting stuck like you are.
